name: sfchronicle
text: Summer camps and park programs in San Francisco will be able to open next month — with several special modifications like limited participants intended to prevent the potential spread of COVID-19. https://t.co/pN575uQlRi

name: sfchronicle
text:
Live Updates: Marin County is aiming to extend its moratorium on residential evictions through June 30 to help tenants impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, county officials said.

https://t.co/wOACtvVp8x

name: sfchronicle
text: The University of San Francisco has agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle claims that the school falsely secured more than $1.7 million in federal grants under the AmeriCorps service program, authorities said Friday. https://t.co/EsqKr3Sxho

name: sfchronicle
text: How do you celebrate Memorial Day in a pandemic? Bay Area officials are warning against people taking holiday weekend drives, though there is one indicator that people are starting to get out: More people are calling AAA to recharge dead car batteries. https://t.co/f4clvDzMsI

name: sfchronicle
text: Live Updates: A pop-up testing site is coming to Mountain View on Memorial Day. People can get tested from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the Rengstorff Park Aquatic Center for free —  no insurance, pre-registration, documentation or appointment required. https://t.co/IZ5qPjT4kQ

name: sfchronicle
text: As the NBA charts a course for resuming play, there’s no good reason to finish the regular season. Just go straight to the playoffs. Writes @Bruce_Jenkins1 https://t.co/R90vANm34P

text: Live Updates: Hertz, the rental car company hard-hit by the pandemic-related restrictions on travel, has filed for bankruptcy protection, the Wall Street Journal reports. https://t.co/7FIhH7Mi4H

name: sfchronicle
text:
Every major industry sector in California lost jobs at unprecedented levels in April as the state’s unemployment rate hit 15.5%.

"The labor market today is much, much worse than a month ago,” said the chief economist at Bank of the West. 

Read more: https://t.co/bxHAYM0YCr https://t.co/JiJ9KEmCf4

text: Live Updates: Health officials confirmed 17 new cases of the coronavirus and no additional deaths on Friday in Marin County, bringing the total case count to 369. In total, 14 people have died and 251 people have recovered. https://t.co/AbQGYZMqwJ

name: sfchronicle
text:
Q: How long does the virus live on grass or trees? Is it safe to sit on the grass at a park?

A: The virus “doesn’t love grass or trees or clothing,” Chin-Hong said. “I would rate these as low-risk surfaces.” Read more:

https://t.co/IamsooD9Sv

text: California voters will decide this November whether to exempt app-based drivers and couriers — like those working for Uber, Lyft and DoorDash — from a state law that sought to classify the drivers as employees. https://t.co/lHE6YNVqLY
